subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I'm going to address the question of
what if I had millions of dollars to
give away
to researchers in the field of
parapsychology,
how would I prioritize things? Let me begin
by saying I'm not an active researcher
myself. Almost all of my
waking time goes into the New Thinking
Allowed video channel. I don't have a million dollars
or many millions, which is really what
would be required.
Nor am I seeking those funds.
But I think it's an interesting question to ask. Suppose
somebody just handed me a budget
of let's say a few million
dollars every year to invest in parapsychology.
The truth is, I do know what my priority
would be and I'm going to explain it to
you now.
It begins I think with the story of
Léon-Hipollyte
Denizard Rivail who was born, as I
recall, in 1804 and died in 1869.
You probably don't know who that is,
however he's well known under his pen
name of Allan
Kardec. He was a professor of pedagogy,
I believe, in France, in Paris.
He actually is the
founder of a religious movement known as
Spiritism. He wrote many books, The
Spirit's Book
is probably his most famous book. But he
developed a protocol which is of great
interest. He began working with spirit
mediums which were very popular
during his own lifetime in the mid
19th century. He had a method, it was
really rather simple. He got mediums
to consult with him and he would ask
them different questions and he simply
suggested that if all seven - I
think he had seven mediums, maybe more -
but when, if I recall correctly, when
seven mediums would agree on a
particular answer to a particular
question or
came into rough agreement he ascribed
that to a level of certainty, of
confidence
that what they were saying was accurate.
Using that methodology he mapped out
what goes on in the spirit world, at
least to the best of his
ability. It was so successful and so
popular that his books
are in publication today
150 years after his death.
So you have to understand, he founded a
new religion but he didn't approach it
as a religion.
He approached it as a
scholarly project
using a method
of inquiry. Now, people will
argue, was his method
scientific? Many people would say, no
it wasn't because there was no
empirical verification.
The verification was based only on
consensus. Yet today
we're in a position where we have
empirical evidence that wasn't available
in Kardec’s
time. We have, for example, the database at
the University of Virginia
where they've been studying cases of the
reincarnation type where young children
report reincarnation memories.
That database has over 2,500
instances in it and I'm pretty sure that
more than half of them have actually been
verified, in the sense that researchers
were able to
collect information from these young
children and
track down the details of the ostensible
past life. So with a lot of information of
an empirical nature about that that
wasn't available in Kardec's lifetime,
or Rivail’s lifetime, if we use his
actual name. Now,
in addition, I have to say to
the methodology used by Rivail, we have
great refinements that have been made to
that methodological
procedure. Now I'm referring to the
remote viewing consensus protocol or
the mobius consensus protocol
developed by my friend Stephan Shwartz
who got teams of remote viewers together
on a number of
projects mostly in the field of
archaeology. There
are any number of interviews about this
now in our archive. I can't link to all
of them because there are so many.
But what I do suggest is that you - for those
viewers who don't understand about our
listings, I will link to that right now, the listings
page on New Thinking Allowed where every
single interview is listed and linked to
on our listing page. You'll see a
number of interviews by Stephan
Shwartz in which
he describes in detail how that protocol works, the great
care that he took to make sure that it was
scientifically reliable and accurate and
the results that he obtained in
areas such as archaeology were very, very
impressive. Now, I think the
goal ought to be to consider,
let's call it the bardo planes, the afterlife,
the supersensible realm
is like an undiscovered continent. I mean,
it's not totally undiscovered because
we have explorations by mystics and
psychics and religious figures going
back millennia, as a matter of fact. But
Rivail, or Kardec
as he is more popularly known, really
did the very first
systematic evaluation of
what this new continent is like,
what it is all about. And you know,
it wasn't all that expensive. He had many
sessions with mediums. I imagine
he invested quite a bit of his money
paying them for their time. If he didn't
perhaps they donated their time. This
research doesn't have to be
terribly expensive. But in addition
to the methodology initiated by Kardec
and the protocols refined
in particular by the work of Stephan
Shwartz, we have other modalities besides
mediumship to consider, the most obvious
being the one utilized by Schwartz
himself, that of remote viewing.
Can we take teams of remote viewers
and ask them to map out for us the
realms of consciousness,
continents of consciousness that
could be explored, things relating to how
reincarnation operates for example,
things relating to
different planes of existence such as
the often discussed and written about
the astral plane,
the higher and the lower astral plane
and other planes
of consciousness. Different systems
describe them in different ways but we
could… we'd have rough maps for sure.
We could begin to create precise maps.
In addition to spirit mediums
and remote viewers we also have
evidence that this realm is accessible
to advanced meditators. Now, I'm
referring to
the research of William Van Gordon
as reported on this channel in which he's
shown that advanced Buddhist meditators
are capable of entering into
a realm very, very comparable
to that reported by near-death
experiencers.
Oh, and near-death experiencers,
also another category.
You might say, how can you research
near-death experience? Well, the truth of
the matter
is that Pim van Lommel has done
exactly that, as reported on this channel. You might think
you never know when somebody's going to
have a near-death experience, they're
usually
quite spontaneous and unpredictable, but
van Lommel has shown that actually,
in the cardiac units of various
hospitals when people
experience cardiac arrest
many of them are clinically dead but then
are revived. He found he was able to do
research on that population. It's a
considerable
population, so that's another category of
experiencers.
Still, these people aren't highly trained
and we only get to them
after the fact, not before the fact. So,
I wouldn't place near-death experiencers
as high on the list
as, for example, people who
train themselves consciously to enter
into states of
lucid dreaming, that's another
category.
So in effect we can be sending
psychonauts
into inner space just as we have sent
astronauts into outer space. I think
it would be a very exciting project.
That's where I
put my money. Now let me ask you: I'm
interested in what viewers have to say.
Suppose you had a few million dollars to research in
some area associated with consciousness,
where would you invest that money?
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
